description:
The bare necessity for pet-loved lawns

Our easy-to-use lawn repair combines urine-resistant seed, slow-release nitrogen, and moisture-holding mulch to repair pet spots, thicken thin spots, stimulate growth, and green your lawn. Pet Lawn Bare Repair grows pet-resistant grass in just two weeks to help you maintain a more durable. pet-friendly lawn that is resistant to future pet spots and thinning areas.

sections.product_benefits:
Made for patching thin or bare areas in lawns
Dark green color and deep rooting
Urine-resistant grass seed mixture—over 160 grass seed varieties tested!
High traffic tolerance with rapid damage recovery
A-LIST-approved seed for quality, sustainability, and reduced maintenance
Grows well in sun to shade and in a wide range of soils
Suitable for any cool-season lawn and grass type
Results in just 14 days
99.9% weed-free guarantee
sections.whats_included:
2 types of premium turf-type tall fescue grass varieties and 1 type of premium perennial ryegrass variety
1-0-0 NPK (nitrogen-phosphorus-potassium) slow-release fertilizer
Moisture-retaining mulch made from recycled paper product
One bag repairs up to 65 sq. ft. of lawn area
Sunday seeding rate
For bare areas: 1 cup per 1 sq. ft.
sections.faq:
Helpful Tips from Lawn Advisors:
What is a urine-resistant seed?
More than 160 varieties of grass seed were tested for highest levels of resiliency to pet urine. Ultimately this combo of tetraploid ryegrass and tall fescue grasses resists the most damage from dog urine.
When to plant fescue grass seed?
The optimal time to seed this mix is during spring and fall when temperatures consistently range between 55 and 75 degrees Fahrenheit.
How long does fescue seed take to grow?
Expect germination in 14 days or less.
Should I use Bare Repair before or after Sunday fertilizer?
You can apply either one first–the order is up to you, and it won’t damage the seed! Since some grass types come up quickly, having some nutrients there can enhance growth.
How to plant bare repair
Prep your soil.
Remove debris and break up exposed soil in bare areas. This ensures seed-to-soil contact, which is essential for the seed to grow.
Spread Bare Repair at the recommended rate.
Spread over patches at a rate of 1 cup per 1 sq. ft. For thinning lawns, apply 1 pound per 15 sq. ft.
Water seeded areas 1–2x daily.
Water in the early morning and evening until grass is about 2” tall. Limit traffic on the newly patched spot until new grass is established.
